Title: How to prove that the rank of a matrix is a lower semi-continuous function?
Content: I need to prove that rank($\mathrm{A}$) is not continuous everywhere but is lower semi-continuous everywhere, where $\mathrm{A}\in \mathbb{C}^{n\times m} $
AcceptedAnswer:
We have to show the set $S = \{A \in \mathbb{C}^{m 	imes n} : 	exttt{rank}(A) > r \} 	ag{1}$ is open for all real $r.$ We need the following fact : given a matrix $A_0 = (a_{ij}^{0})$ of rank $r_0$ there is a $\delta > 0$ such that for any  matrix $A=(a_{ij})$ with $\|A - A_0\|_{	exttt{max}} < \delta$ (i,e., $ |a_{ij} - a^0_{ij}| < \delta\   orall i,j$) we have $	exttt{rank}(A) \geq r_0.$ The proof of this is straightforward, if $r_0 = 0$ the result is immediate, if $r_0 > 0$ there is a $r_0 	imes r_0$ non-singular submatrix in $A_0$, call this submatrix $A^{r_0}_0$. We have $	exttt{det}(A_0^{r^0}) 
eq 0.$ By continuity of determinant there is a $\delta > 0$ such that for any $r_0 	imes r_0$ matrix $B$ with $\|A_0^{r^0} - B\|_{	exttt{max}} < \delta$ we have $	exttt{det}(B) 
eq 0.$ So if $A$ is any matrix with $\|A - A_0\|_{	exttt{max}} < \delta$ and $A^{r^0}$ is the submatrix of $A$ with the same indices that determine $A_0^{r^0}$ then $\|A^{r^0} - A_0^{r^0}\|_{	exttt{max}} \leq \|A-A_0\|_{	exttt{max}} < \delta$ which implies $	exttt{det}(A^{r^0}) 
eq 0$ so $	exttt{rank}(A) \geq r_0.$ Now we can easily prove $(1)$.  If $S$ is non-empty choose $A_0 \in S$ we have $	exttt{rank}(A_0) > r$. We can find $\delta > 0$ such that for any $A$ with $\|A-A_0\|_{	exttt{max}} < \delta$ we have  $	exttt{rank}(A) \geq 	exttt{rank}(A_0) > r$, so $A \in S$ and $S$ is open. It is easy to see rank is not a continuous function : each element in the sequence of matrices $ egin{pmatrix} \dfrac{1}{n} & 0 \ 0 & \dfrac{1}{n} \end{pmatrix}$ has rank 2, but the limit has rank 0.
